facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 46 to 48 of 1956 appealed from judgment and order dated November 16, 1951 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 45, 1568 and 1569 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 46 to 48 of 1956. Appeals from the judgment and order dated November 16, 1951, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 45,1568 and 1569 of 1951.

facts.text: Appellant employed in 1939 in Bengal Nagpur Railway as clerk in workshop at Nagpur

anchor.surface_text: The facts in Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956-the facts in the companynected appeals are similar and do number require to be stated-are that the appellant was employed in 1939 in the Bengal Nagpur Railway as a clerk in the workshop at Nagpur.

facts.text: In 1946 State took over administration of Railway and gave option to employees to continue on terms in document dated July 5, 1946

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 when the State took over the administration of the Railway, it gave option to the employees to companytinue in service on the terms set out in a document dated July 5, 1946.

facts.text: Appellant accepted terms and continued in service on conditions in document dated July 5, 1946

anchor.surface_text: The appellant accepted those terms and companytinued in service on the companyditions mentioned in that document.

facts.text: Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949 promulgated by Governor-General under ss. 241, 247, 266 of Government of India Act, 1935, came into force May 14, 1949

anchor.surface_text: Acting in exercise of the powers companyferred by ss. 241 2 , 247 and 266 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, the Governor-General promulgated certain rules called the Railway Services  Safeguarding of National Security  Rules, 1949, hereinafter referred to as the Security Rules, and they came into force on May 14, 1949.

facts.text: On July 6, 1950, General Manager of Bengal Nagpur Railway issued notice to appellant under R.3 of Security Rules stating reason to believe engaged in subversive activities, called to show cause, placed under suspension

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950, the General Manager of the Bengal Nagpur Railway issued a numberice to the appellant 1056 under R. 3 of the Security Rules stating that in view of the facts recited therein, there was reason to believe that the appellant was engaged in subversive activities and calling upon him to show cause why his services should number be terminated. He was also placed under suspension from that date.

facts.text: On July 29, 1950, appellant sent explanation denying allegations in notice dated July 6, 1950

anchor.surface_text: On July 29, 1950, the appellant sent his explanation denying the allegations companytained in the numberice dated July 6, 1950.

facts.text: Committee of Advisers held enquiry on September 8, 1950, after hearing appellant found charges true

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then referred to the Committee of Advisers, who held an enquiry on September 8,1950, and after hearing the appellant found that the charges against him mentioned in the numberice were true.

facts.text: On April 3, 1951, General Manager terminated services of appellant giving one month's salary instead of notice, acting on Committee report

anchor.surface_text: Acting on this report, the General Manager terminated the services of the appellant on April 3, 1951, giving him one months salary instead of numberice.

facts.text: On February 3, 1951, appellant filed writ petition in Nagpur High Court challenging notice dated July 6, 1950 and suspension, later amended to include dismissal order

anchor.surface_text: Meantime, on February 3,1951, the appellant had filed the writ petition, out of which Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956 arises, in the High Court of Nagpur challenging the validity of the numberice dated July 6, 1950, and the order of suspension following thereon. The order of dismissal dated April 3, 195 1, having been passed during the pendency of this Petition, the appellant had his petition amended by adding a prayer that that order also was bad.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court by judgment dated November 16, 1951 held unnecessary to decide validity of Security Rules, sustained orders under R.148(3) and (4) of Railway Establishment Code, dismissed petitions

anchor.surface_text: by their judgment dated November 16, 1951, the learned Judges held that it was unnecessary to decide whether the Security Rules were void as, assuming that they were, the orders terminating the services of the petitioners companyld be sustained under R. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code.

facts.text: Present appeals preferred against High Court orders on certificate under Art. 132(1) and Art. 133(1)(c) of Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the petitions were dismissed, and the present appeals have been preferred against these orders on a certificate under Art. 132  1  and Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants contended Security Rules in contravention of Arts. 14, 19(1)(c) and 311 of Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The grounds urged in support of the petition were that the Security Rules under which action was taken were in companytravention of Arts. 14, 19  1  c  and 311 of the Constitution

facts.text: Respondents resisted saying rules valid and orders not open to attack

anchor.surface_text: The respondents resisted the application on the ground that the rules in question were valid, and that the orders passed thereunder were number open to attack.

facts.text: Supreme Court heard appeals together as arising from same facts and raising same points

anchor.surface_text: These appeals are directed against the orders of the High Court of Nagpur dismissing the writ petitions filed by the appellants herein, and as they arise out of the same facts and raise the same points for determination, they were heard together, and will be disposed of by a companymon judgment.

facts.text: Notice dated July 6, 1950 stated appellant reasonably suspected member and office secretary of B.N. Rly. Workers Union (Communist sponsored), associated with communists in subversive activities, attended private meetings, agitated for general strike Nov 1948 to Jan 1949

anchor.surface_text: The numberice, so far as it is material, runs as follows- Whereas in the opinion of the General ,Manager, you are reasonably suspected to be a member and office secretary of the B. N. Rly. Workers Union  Communist sponsored  and were thickly associated with companymunists such as Om Prakash Mehta, B.N. Mukherjee, R. L. Reddy, etc., in subversive activities in such manner as to raise doubts about your reliability and loyalty to the State in that, though a Government employee, you attended private meetings of the Communists, carried on agitation amongst the Railway workers for a general strike from November 1948 to January 1949 evidently to paralyse companymunication and movement of essential supplies - and thereby create disorder and companyfusion in the companyntry and that, companysequently, you are liable to have your services terminated under rule 3 of the said Rules.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Security Rules not repugnant to Art. 14 as classification based on subversive activities in context of national security is valid

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the Security Rules are number illegal as being repugnant -to ,a Art. 14.

facts.text: Supreme Court held orders not in contravention of Art. 19(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: This companytention of the appellants must also be rejected.

facts.text: Supreme Court held termination under R.3 not dismissal or removal under Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: The order terminating the services under R. 3 of the Security Rules stands on the same footing as an order of discharge under R. 148, and it is neither one of dismissal number of removal within the meaning of Art. 311.

holdings.text: We hold that the Security Rules are not illegal as being repugnant to Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the Security Rules are number illegal as being repugnant -to ,a Art. 14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification of railway servants suspected of subversive activities prejudicial to national security satisfies Art.14: intelligible differentia with rational relation to object of rules; 'subversive activities' precise in national security context; follows Budhan Choudhry test; distinguishes Anwar Ali Sarkar.

holdings.text: In our judgment, the words subversive activities in the context of national security are sufficiently precise in their import to sustain a valid classification.

anchor.surface_text: The only point that calls for decision in these appeals is whether the classi- fication of persons on the basis of subversive activities is too vague to be the foundation of a valid classification. ... In our judgment, the words subversive activities in the companytext of national security are sufficiently precise in their import to sustain a valid classification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expression not vague when read with rules' object (safeguarding national security) and R.3 requirement (retention prejudicial to security); prior conduct relevant but rules prospective.

holdings.text: This contention of the appellants must also be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention of the appellants must also be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination does not infringe Art.19(1)(c) as does not prevent continuing communist or trade union activities; no fundamental right to continued state employment.

holdings.text: The order terminating the services under R. 3 of the Security Rules stands on the same footing as an order of discharge under R. 148, and it is neither one of dismissal nor of removal within the meaning of Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: The order terminating the services under R. 3 of the Security Rules stands on the same footing as an order of discharge under R. 148, and it is neither one of dismissal number of removal within the meaning of Art. 311.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not punitive: no premature termination of fixed tenure; no forfeiture of accrued benefits (R.7 preserves); applies Parshotam Lal Dhingra test; follows prior SC cases.

holdings.text: But Art. 311 has application only when there is an order of dismissal or removal, and the question is whether an order terminating the services of the employees under R. 3 can be said to be an order dismissing or removing them... [no].

anchor.surface_text: But Art. 311 has application only when there is an order of dismissal or removal, and the question is whether an order terminating the services of the employees under R. 3 can be said to be an order dismissing or removing them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination simpliciter, not by way of punishment; no right to tenure or loss of benefits.

holdings.text: The impugned orders are valid even according to the Security Rules.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950, the General Manager... issued a notice... show cause... explanation sent... Committee of Advisers held enquiry... found charges true... General Manager terminated services...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure under R.3-5 followed: notice of grounds, opportunity to show cause, consideration of representation, committee enquiry, prior approval obtained.

holdings.text: Those orders were passed by the competent authorities.

anchor.surface_text: I have decided with the prior approval of the President that your services should be terminated under Rule 3...

holdings.reasoning_summary: General Manager is competent authority under rules; prior approval of President/Governor-General obtained as required.

holdings.text: The rules are clearly prospective in that action thereunder is to be taken in respect of subversive activities which either now exist or are likely to be indulged in, in future... That the materials for taking action... drawn from the conduct... prior to the enactment of the rules does not render their operation retrospective.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the rules provide that action can be taken under them, if the employee is engaged or is reasonably suspected to be engaged in subversive activities... antecedents must furnish the best materials... does number render their operation retrospective.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Antecedents relevant to form opinion on present/future reliability; rules apply prospectively to decision, not events.

holdings.text: We find considerable difficulty in acceding to the argument of the respondents. The Security Rules... form a self-contained code prescribing a special and elaborate procedure... have an independent operation of their own, quite apart from R. 148.

anchor.surface_text: We find companysiderable difficulty in acceding to the argument of the respondents. The Security Rules apply to a special class of employees, those who are engaged or are likely to engage

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authorities invoked only Security Rules (notice, procedure, order recite R.3); not pleaded as R.148; rules independent for special cases, not reducible to general discharge power.

precedents.citation: Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry. 1

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, that has been held in Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry.  1  and Prasadi v. Works Manager, Lillooah  2  and that is also companyceded by .Mr. Ganapathy Iyer. If then the power to terminate the service under the Security Rules is different from the power to discharge under R. 148 when the procedure prescribed therein is number followed, it must be equally so when, as here, it has been followed, for the companyplexion of the rules cannot change according as they are companyplied with or number.

precedents.case_name: Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry.
precedents.cited_proposition: If procedure under Security Rules not followed, order bad and R.148 cannot be invoked to validate it

anchor.surface_text: Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry.  1  and Prasadi v. Works Manager, Lillooah  2  and that is also companyceded by .Mr. Ganapathy Iyer. If then the power to terminate the service under the Security Rules is different from the power to discharge under R. 148 when the procedure prescribed therein is number followed, it must be equally so when, as here, it has been followed, for the companyplexion of the rules cannot change according as they are companyplied with or number. That means that the Security Rules have an independent operation of their own, quite apart from R. 148.

precedents.cited_proposition: If procedure under Security Rules not followed, order bad and R.148 cannot be invoked to validate it

precedents.citation: The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was placed on the decision of this Court in The State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar  1 , wherein it was held that a power companyferred on the executive to select cases for trial by special companyrts under a procedure different from that of the ordinary companyrts with the object of ensuring speedy trial companyld number be upheld under Art. 14 as a valid classification, and on the decision of the Madras High Court in Ananthanarayanan v. Southern Railway 2 , wherein it was hold that the words subversive activities in R. 3 lacked definiteness.

precedents.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents.cited_proposition: Power conferred on executive to select cases for trial by special courts for speedy trial not valid classification under Art.14
precedents.cited_holding: Power to select cases for special courts invalid under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: , and on the decision of the Madras High Court in Ananthanarayanan v. Southern Railway 2 , wherein it was hold that the words subversive activities in R. 3 lacked definiteness. Now, the principles applicable for a determination whether there has been a proper and valid classification for purposes of Art. 14 have been the subject of companysideration by this Court in a number of cases, and they were stated again quite recently in Budhan Choudhry and others v. The State of Bihar 3 , and there is numberneed to repeat them.

precedents.cited_proposition: Words 'subversive activities' in R.3 lack definiteness
precedents.cited_holding: 'subversive activities' lacks definiteness even with national security

precedents.citation: Budhan Choudhry and others v. The State of Bihar 3

anchor.surface_text: in a number of cases, and they were stated again quite recently in Budhan Choudhry and others v. The State of Bihar 3 , and there is numberneed to repeat them. The only point that  1  1952 S.C.R. 284.  2  A.I.R. 1956 Mad. 220.  3  19551 S.C.R. 1045, 1049. 1063 calls for decision in these appeals is whether the classi- fication of persons on the basis of subversive activities is too vague to be the foundation of a valid classification.

precedents.case_name: Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles applicable for determining valid classification under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the opinion expressed in Ananthanarayanan v. Southern Railway  supra  at p. 223 that the language of R. 3 is indefinite, even when read with the words national security. We are also unable to agree with the argument of the appellants based on the charges made against the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956 in the numberice dated July 6, 1950, that the expression subversive activities is wide enough to take in lawful activities as well, and must therefore be held to be unreasonable for purposes of classification under Art. 14.

precedents.citation: Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Vide Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India  1 , Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India  2 , State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3 , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4 . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra .

precedents.case_name: Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Not every termination of service is dismissal or removal under Art.311; only if by way of punishment

precedents.citation: Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India  1 , Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India  2 , State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3 , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4 . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment.

precedents.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Not every termination of service is dismissal or removal under Art.311; only if by way of punishment

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi 3

anchor.surface_text: Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India  2 , State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3 , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4 . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi
precedents.cited_proposition: Not every termination of service is dismissal or removal under Art.311; only if by way of punishment

precedents.citation: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India 4

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3 , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4 . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: What amounts to punishment for Art.311: premature termination if right to continue, or loss of accrued benefits
precedents.cited_holding: Termination is punishment if it affects right to continue or accrued benefits

anchor.surface_text: The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment. In the present case, the terms of employment provide for the services being terminated on a proper numberice, and so, numberquestion of permature termination arises.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: What amounts to punishment for Art.311
